ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had zoom classes 3 times a week and asynchronous learning with videos to watch twice a week.

informational videos
website activities
We also had assigned videos to watch before each class.
Live lectures and discussion sections in addition to asynchronous material.
Monday and Wednesday watch video supplements. Wednesday working in small groups. Thursday and Friday attend live classes on zoom.
N/A
live virtual section as well
Group work days

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the basics of the Arabic language and fell in love with the Arabic culture.
Introduction to the Arabic language including the alphabet and grammar basics
Arabic alphabet, a lot of vocabulary, sentence structure and some basic conversation.
We learned grammar (verbs, nouns, pronouns) and how to form sentences. We started conversing and writing paragraphs.
I began with no knowledge of Arabic, and learned the foundations of the language. This includes the script, basic conversation and introductions, and the beginnings of grammar.
A good introduction and base to learning Arabic reading writing and speaking.
I learned the basics of Arabic, the alphabet, important information about the difference between MSA and dialects, how to write and read basic sentences.
I learned Arabic! I also learned a lot about just the origins and construction of language.
I learned introductory Arabic and its linguistic applications and grammar.

I learned how to read and write Arabic at a basic level, including important vocabulary used on a daily basis. You learn how to describe yourself, your family, conjugate verbs, grammar, etc. A large emphasis is also placed on being able to have a conversation with an Arabic speaker. You will learn a lot in this class, particularly with Professor Elbousty.
Good handle on the arabic alphabet, basic msa vocab and intro grammar

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is very interactive and thus helpful to learn a new language. The professor too is very understanding and helpful.
This course was excellent, the pacing and assignments were great. The only complaint would be the textbook and its companion website being of not great quality (which is not the professor's fault).

Professor Elbousty's energy is amazing. He's so encouraging, which is so important when learning a difficult language like Arabic. He genuinely cares about all his students. I can't think of any weaknesses.

Strengths: The professor is very organised and knowledgeable. The TA was very helpful and informative
Weaknesses: There wasn't an efficient way of getting feedback on work or progress.

The strengths of this course are the professor and the high level of class engagement. The weaknesses are that in a virtual language class it is hard to get enough time speaking and listening to Arabic. The virtual environment also makes it hard to meet other students or get help.

Really amazing foundations course! Strengths are the supportive environment, the wonderful Professor Elbousty and TA Bayan, and the Arabic skills gained. Vocabulary could be reviewed more in class but the grammar powerpoints made by the professor were very helpful.

We discussed these changes with Professor Elbousty, but teaching an introductory level language course over zoom for the first time is incredibly challenging (especially Arabic!). We discussed more structured time and what resources should be brought to the table.
Incredible instructors, both for section and lecture. Very thorough content instruction

This class, when taught by Professor Elbousty, largely lacks weaknesses. It is engaging, and Professor Elbousty is to thank for that, as he is also engaged and passionate about making sure his students learn the material well. I would say that the way this course is taught truly teaches you a comprehensive basic understanding of Arabic, including reading, writing, and speaking. The only thing I would change is perhaps make sure that the content of the videos we watch when we don't have live lecture doesn't repeat itself, as I found that occurred more than once.

It was a little disorganized - due dates and assignments were unclear - i think it would have helped to have the assignments on canvas be more descriptive (i.e. list the exercises we were supposed to do, rather than just a generic assignment name).I think it actually would've helped to have vocab quizzes earlier. Being called on in class was very helpful and helped me understand pitfalls/mistakes i was making a lot better. i really appreciated the class environment - Prof. Elbousty made it very fun and comfortable, and I even made some friends, which is amazing to have happened over zoom. The group work days were really nice because it's helpful to practice with others so that you can ask questions and learn from each other. More music would have been nice:) and the written conversations.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The powerpoints were really effective and it was useful being able to look back at them.

We incorporated more videos to watch on our own time 2 days a week instead of meeting for class. When we did meet, PowerPoints were used for lectures and we often split into breakout rooms of 2-3 people to practice a conversation, which we would then each say to the class. Additionally, the inclusion of a short section with a TA once a week to answer any questions missed in class and review material/prepare for tests were really helpful!

What succeeded were the extra study sessions on weekends that were 2 hours long. Those sessions were more personalized and very valuable.what failed was the online learning software and getting enough time to speak or hear the language.
Super nice have two class days be asynchronous. Gives us more time to do the homework for Wednesday. Grammar powerpoints were very helpful. I also liked having a designated day for group work.

Professor Elbousty was a great resource and so was Bayan the TA (discussion section). We discussed improvement already, but some of the course lacked structure but that was part of the transition period.
Zooming was utilized and it was very effective given the COVID 19 circumstances.

As stated before, the videos we watch when we don't have lecture sometimes overlapped in content, which could be improved. Live virtual seminars did work well, and live/in-person is the only way learning a language properly would be feasible. However, live virtual seminars do result in a number of technological issues which are hard to solve, but nonetheless are important to note.

Group work days and breakout rooms were helpful. I think especially because it's virtual, its more important for it to be organized - there was a lot of consistent confusion over the syllabus and canvas postings throughout the semester, which made it really hard for me to get in a good rhythm and form good practice habits. Sticking to a daily schedule over the semester, at least in terms of what exercises and outside videos to watch by what day, would be nice.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely. Arabic is an amazing language.
Yes, if you want to learn Arabic you will not be disappointed with this course.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Arabic is a beautiful language and learning a new alphabet is awesome.
Definitely. Especially if you're lucky enough to have Professor Elbousty as your teacher.
Yes. It is very effective in introducing the language.

I would absolutely recommend this class to anyone interested in Arabic or the Near East. Even if it's the only course you take, you come out confident in your foundational skills of MSA. Both vocabulary and grammar are learned at a reasonable pace and we get a good amount of practice in writing and conversation.

I would recommend this course to any student who wants to learn arabic, due to the great professor. However I would caution them to be aware of the inherent struggle of learning this language vs others, exacerbated by the virtual environment
Yes! Super fun! Take with a friend!
Absolutely! Professor Elbousty is such an engaging professor. If you want to learn Arabic, he can definitely teach you!
Yes, these instructors helped my introduction a daunting language path pass smoothly.

Yes! Take it with Professor Elbousty if you can, he is a fantastic professor. He really cares about the students at a personal level, and is passionate about making sure the students learn the material properly. Professor Elbousty is understanding, personable, and a fantastic teacher. He will even hold extra sessions before tests to make sure everyone who needs a little extra help gets it. The TA for this class was also very helpful and sections were largely focused on things that people had difficulty with, so make sure to use this to your advantage. Make sure you do all the homework as well, as learning a language really requires daily application of it. I took this class as a virtual seminar during the COVID-19 pandemic and still learned a lot of Arabic, despite already knowing how to speak a specific dialect. You will learn how to hold multiple conversations, a number of grammar rules, and how to read and write at a basic level, and most of all, you will always be engaged in learning the language. Do not worry about mispronouncing something or getting something wrong in class either, even if some people appear to have less/more trouble with doing the same. At the end of the day, everyone is there to learn Arabic, and this learning is facilitated very well.
I hear that usually this is a heavy language course, but i think it was dialed back for ZoomU. I really enjoyed it.
